arm_group.description: Group1 (n=30): overweight and obese (BMI ≥25 and/ or WHtR≥0.5)
Group2 (n=30): normal weight (BMI ≥ 18 to < 25 and/or WHtR ≥0.4 to <0.5)
Control Group (n= 20): healthy subjects, matched for age and gender, were included in this study. All included controls had average weight (BMI ≥ 18 to < 25 and/ or WHtR ≥0.4 to <0.5)

brief_summary.textblock:
evaluate the impact of different anthropometric measures on clinical and endoscopic severity
      of GERD and its relation to serum leptin.

clinical_study.brief_title: Anthropometric Measures and Severity of Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria:

          -  Gastro esophageal reflux symptoms (e.g. heart burn, regurgitation, water brash or
             atypical symptoms such as hoarseness of voice, asthma and cough)

          -  complete upper gastrointestinal endoscopy.

        Exclusion Criteria:

          -  Receiving medication for reflux disease (including proton pump inhibitor, histamine
             type 2 receptors blocker, prokinetic agents) in the previous month.

          -  Pregnant woman.

          -  History of upper abdominal surgery.

          -  Severe co-morbidity as cirrhosis, end-stage renal disease and heart failure.

study_pop.textblock:
This prospective, case-controlled study included 60 Egyptian patients who attended Ain
        Shams University Hospitals and Theodor Bilharz Research Institute; Cairo, Egypt

clinical_study.keyword: Gastroesophageal Reflux Disease; Anthropometric Measures; Leptin

primary_outcome.description: evaluate the impact of different anthropometric measures on clinical and endoscopic severity of GERD and its relation to serum leptin.
primary_outcome.measure: Impact of anthropometric measures on GERD

required_header.download_date: ClinicalTrials.gov processed this data on June 04, 2014
required_header.link_text: Link to the current ClinicalTrials.gov record.

responsible_party.investigator_title: Lecturer of tropical medicine , Ain Shams university

clinical_study.study_design: Observational Model: Case Control, Time Perspective: Prospective
